clinical_study.brief_title: Adolescent Idiopathic Scoliosis and Proprioceptive Defect
clinical_study.official_title: The Role of Proprioceptive Deficits in the Progression of Adolescent Idiopathic Scoliosis

brief_summary.textblock: This is the first research study to examine the peripheral and spinal proprioceptive deficits in AIS subjects in a comprehensive manner. It will determine normative values with reference to age, the relationship of proprioceptive changes to curve pattern, magnitude and progression, as well as whether all joints are equally affected, and thus address definitively the contribution of spinal proprioception to aetiology. Furthermore, as little is known about the measurement of proprioceptive sense, the present protocol from the study could be a reference measurement guide for detecting the proprioceptive sense in normal individuals, as well as to identify those with high risk for curve progression.

primary_outcome.description: The CE is the positive/negative difference between the position that was actively achieved by the subject and the target position.
The AE is the average absolute deviation between the position achieved by the subject and the target position.
The VE is the difference between the position achieved by the subject on each trial and the subject's own average error.
The TE is the sum of the squared differences, in which each difference is the amount by which the subject missed the target angle for a given trial.

study_pop.textblock: All patients diagnosed AIS presenting to the Duchess of Kent Children's Hospital at Sandy Bay in Hong Kong will be screened for enrollment. Medical record will be evaluated to confirm the eligibility.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients cannot receive previous conservative and surgical intervention for AIS in order to prevent any potential inferences of treatment
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients will be excluded if they have Chiari malformation, syringomyelia, developmental delay, or symptomatic spondylolisthesis
